talk.author: did:plc:4czc4jsssc25mxj6jlauvten
talk.utter: i get the concern, but seeing .gov domains would help drive home what actually constitutes an authoritative us gov account. if anything, seeing a gov from the us that doesn't use .gov looks incredibly weird.

talk.author: did:plc:4czc4jsssc25mxj6jlauvten
talk.utter: already, people know to look for ".gov". and the usual attempt to hide with stuff like "thing.gov-some-obviously-fake-path.malicious.example" would stick out like a sore thumb, in stark contrast to urls where that hyphen could be misread as a slash.

talk.author: did:plc:4czc4jsssc25mxj6jlauvten
talk.utter: scammers could try stunts like ".got" instead of ".gov" tho, and that is of concern. i'll file a feature request against the app to help catch that low-hanging fruit.

talk.author: did:plc:ffstfhmcqcmobvr5klyw6aju

talk.author: did:plc:ffstfhmcqcmobvr5klyw6aju
talk.utter: And the problem is not only with government sites, but, maybe even more, with commercial (banking, webshops, travel) organizations. wells-fargo, wellsfargo or wellsfargo-bank.com? Imho it's not fair to expect an ordinary user to recognize all possible scam-techniques.

talk.author: did:plc:ffstfhmcqcmobvr5klyw6aju

talk.author: did:plc:4czc4jsssc25mxj6jlauvten
talk.utter:
gov domains are usually very discoverable. and ideally, we'd have something like the timezone database for these domains, but afaict there isn't such a thing.

such a database would be incredibly valuable for more than just bluesky, but browsers and spam detectors as well.
